questions.prompt: Under the associated variable convention, current is defined as positive when it:
questions.explanation: The associated variable convention defines positive current as entering the positive voltage terminal. This ensures that P = VI is positive when the element absorbs power (like a resistor). This is a bookkeeping rule, not a physical law.

questions.prompt: What does the V-I characteristic of an ideal wire look like?
options: A line through the origin with slope R
A vertical line at V = E
questions.explanation: An ideal wire has V = 0 for any current. On a V-I plot (V horizontal, I vertical), this is a vertical line along the I-axis. The current can be anything, but the voltage is always zero because the resistance is zero.

questions.prompt: On a V-I plot (I on vertical axis, V on horizontal axis), the slope of a resistor's characteristic line equals:
questions.explanation: From V = IR, we get I = V/R = GV. The slope ΔI/ΔV = 1/R = G (conductance in siemens). A steeper line means lower resistance. This is a common confusion point — the slope is G, not R.

questions.prompt: An ideal current source has a V-I characteristic that is:
questions.explanation: An ideal current source maintains I = I₀ regardless of voltage. On a V-I plot, this is a horizontal line at I = I₀. The voltage across the source adjusts to whatever the circuit demands.

questions.prompt: A battery has EMF E = 12V and internal resistance R_int = 0.5Ω. What is the terminal voltage when it delivers 4A?
questions.explanation: Using the Thévenin model: V = E - I·R_int = 12 - 4(0.5) = 12 - 2 = 10V. The internal resistance causes a 2V drop, so the terminal voltage is less than the EMF when current is being drawn.

questions.prompt: What is the short-circuit current of a battery with E = 9V and R_int = 0.3Ω?
questions.explanation: At short-circuit, V = 0, so 0 = E - I·R_int, giving I_SC = E/R_int = 9/0.3 = 30A. This dangerous current is why batteries can cause fires — the internal resistance is very low, allowing very large short-circuit currents.

questions.prompt: Three resistors with conductances G₁ = 2S, G₂ = 3S, and G₃ = 5S are connected in parallel. What is the total conductance?
questions.explanation: For parallel resistors, total conductance is simply G_total = G₁ + G₂ + G₃ = 2 + 3 + 5 = 10S. This is why conductance is easier to work with for parallel combinations — you just add directly instead of using the reciprocal formula.

questions.prompt: A 1kΩ resistor has 5V across it. The power absorbed by the resistor is:
questions.explanation: P = V²/R = 25/1000 = 0.025W = 25mW. Alternatively, I = V/R = 5mA, so P = VI = 5V × 5mA = 25mW. All three power formulas (VI, I²R, V²/R) give the same positive result — a resistor always absorbs power.

questions.prompt: The V-I characteristic of a battery with internal resistance has:
options: Negative slope (falling from left to right)
questions.correctAnswer: Negative slope (falling from left to right)
questions.explanation: From V = E - I·R_int, rearranging: I = (E - V)/R_int = -V/R_int + E/R_int. The slope ΔI/ΔV = -1/R_int, which is negative. As more current is drawn, the terminal voltage drops — giving a line that falls from left to right.

questions.prompt: An element has V = 10V across it and I = -2A (using associated convention). The element is:
questions.explanation: P = VI = 10 × (-2) = -20W. A negative power under the associated convention means the element is delivering power, not absorbing it. This element is acting as a source — like a battery powering a circuit.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is NOT a property of an ideal voltage source?
options: It maintains constant voltage regardless of current
Its V-I characteristic is a vertical line
It can only deliver current in one direction
questions.correctAnswer: It can only deliver current in one direction
questions.explanation: An ideal voltage source maintains V = E for ANY current — positive, negative, or zero. It can both deliver and absorb current. The constraint is on voltage, not on current direction. Its V-I plot is vertical (any I, fixed V), confirming zero internal resistance.

questions.prompt: Two resistors have the same V-I slope on a V-I plot. What can you conclude?
options: They have the same voltage across them
questions.explanation: The slope on a V-I plot (I vertical, V horizontal) is G = 1/R. Same slope means same conductance, which means same resistance. However, the actual current, voltage, and power depend on how they're connected in the circuit — the V-I line only tells you the element relationship, not the operating point.
